Key Arguments: The legislation is seen as a form of censorship that targets social media while giving traditional media, particularly those owned by foreign entities like Murdoch, a free pass.
The bill is perceived as part of a global trend towards controlling information, aligned with international organizations like the USA, IMF, WEF, and WHO, which are accused of unethical power grabs.
There is a belief that the legislation will suppress free speech and prevent the public from being informed about government corruption and other important issues.
The submission argues that the true solution to misinformation is open public debate and a transparent government, not censorship.
The bill is viewed as a threat to democracy and an improper manipulation of Australians.
Notable Quotes: This bill to censor social media whilst giving Murdoch (American) a free pass in Australia.
The free speech of Australians comes under attack by our own representatives.
This Bill presents a greater threat to Australia than the thing it claims to combat.
The only cure for mis and disinformation is open public debate with a transparent government that is held to account.
